Award.AwardTitle: Aluminous phase at high-pressures & temperatures: Elasticity and Energetics of hydrogen incorporation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Geophysical and geochemical observations provide insights into the physical and chemical states of the Earth's interior. However, only by comparing mineral physics data (physical properties) with geophysical (seismological) observations can we disentangle the thermal state of the deep Earth from its chemistry. Conventionally, as a first order approximation, the Earth's mantle is thought to be composed of a homogenous pyrolite. However, the distinct trace element signatures in mid ocean ridge and ocean island basalts reveal the heterogeneity in the Earth's mantle. Although the scale of the heterogeneity is unknown, it is likely that large regions of the mantle are composed of a depleted harzburgite and enriched crustal fractions. We have limited knowledge of the thermodynamics and physical properties of mineral phases in these subducted crusts at high pressures.

In this proposal, the PI intends to use first principles calculations to investigate how chemistry influences crystal structure, energetics, and elasticity of aluminous mineral phases which are likely to be stabilized in deeply subducted oceanic and continental crusts. He will also investigate the energetics of hydrogen incorporation within these aluminous phases. The results will be relevant for geophysics, mineral-physics, geodynamics, petrology, and geochemistry sub disciplines. The PI will also train undergraduate student/s in Solid Earth Geosciences/Mineral Physics.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the project "Aluminous phase at high-pressures & temperatures: Elasticity and Energetics of hydrogen incorporation" PI and his group examined mineral phases that are key players in transporting water into the deep Earth via subduction process. So far, in the community focus has been on major mantle minerals and their hydrated counterparts. this certainly makes sense since they would dominate the bulk of the mantle. However, it is clear that major mantle hydrous phases have limited thermal stability and they are unlikely to be efficient host of water and in subduction zone settings they are likely to dehydrate at shallower depths corresponding to modest temperature and pressures. The key question is are there any other mineral phase that could efficiently host water and be thermodynamically stable at mantle conditions? Through this grant PI and his group explored aluminous hydrous phases, which are minor phases in the mantle but have high thermal stability and thus are efficient transporter of water into deep Earth. PI investigated the structure, equation of state, and elasticity using a combination of simulation and experiments. PI and his team explored several phases including albite, phase PI, topaz, and phase Egg. Although, the funding has come to an end, PI is extending this area of research into answering questions about newly found superhydrated kaolinite and trying address fundamental question about how volume of a phase could expand at high pressures? PI is using NSF funded Raman Spectrometer to address this question.

This project has partly funded four post-doctoral scholars, two of them have moved on to successful jobs in academia and in industry. The project has also involved several undergraduate students, few of whom have gone to graduate prestigious graduate program including Brown University. The project has also involved underrepresented students from high schools in Florida who have also been admitted to undergraduate programs across the US.
